Communication-Efficient Federated Learning
through Importance Sampling

Berivan Isik
Stanford University
berivan.isik@stanford.edu
&Francesco Pase∗
University of Padova
pasefrance@dei.unipd.it

Abstract

The high communication cost of sending model updates from the clients to the server is a significant bottleneck for scalable federated learning (FL). Among existing approaches, state-of-the-art bitrate-accuracy tradeoffs have been achieved using stochastic compression methods – in which the client n𝑛n sends a sample from a client-only probability distribution qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}}, and the server estimates the mean of the clients’ distributions using these samples. However, such methods do not take full advantage of the FL setup where the server, throughout the training process, has side information in the form of a pre-data distribution pθsubscript𝑝𝜃p_{\theta} that is close to the client’s distribution qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}} in Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence. In this work, we exploit this closeness between the clients’ distributions qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}}’s and the side information pθsubscript𝑝𝜃p_{\theta} at the server, and propose a framework that requires approximately DK​L(qϕ(n)||pθ)D_{KL}(q_{\phi^{(n)}}||p_{\theta}) bits of communication. We show that our method can be integrated into many existing stochastic compression frameworks such as FedPM [19], Federated SGLD [41], and QSGD [2] to attain the same (and often higher) test accuracy with up to 505050 times reduction in the bitrate.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL), while enabling model training without collecting clients’ raw data, suffers from high communication costs due to the model updates communicated from the clients to the server every round [21]. To mitigate this cost, several communication-efficient FL strategies have been developed that compress the model updates, such as sparsification [3, 18, 26, 31, 42], quantization [2, 5, 28, 44], low-rank factorization [4, 22, 39, 38], and sparse network training [19]. Many of these strategies adopt a stochastic approach that requires the client n𝑛n to send a sample 𝐱(t,n)superscript𝐱𝑡𝑛\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)} from a client-only distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}} (which we call the post-data distribution), while the goal of the server is to estimate 𝔼X(t,n)∼qϕ(t,n),∀n∈[N]​[1N​∑n=1NX(t,n)]subscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝑋𝑡𝑛\mathbb{E}_{X^{(t,n)}\sim q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}},\forall n\in[N]}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}X^{(t,n)}\right] by taking the average of the samples across clients 1N​∑n=1N𝐱(t,n)1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝐱𝑡𝑛\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)}. Here, we denote by N𝑁N the number of clients, by [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N] the set {1,…,N}1…𝑁\{1,\dots,N\}, and by 𝐚i(t,n)subscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑡𝑛𝑖\mathbf{a}^{(t,n)}_{i} the i𝑖i-th parameter of a vector 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} at client n𝑛n in round t𝑡t. We show that in many stochastic FL settings, the server also holds a distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} (which we call the pre-data distribution) that is close to the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}} (which is unknown to the server) in KL divergence. The proposed method, KL Minimization with Side Information (𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS}), exploits this closeness to reduce the cost of communicating samples 𝐱(t,n)superscript𝐱𝑡𝑛\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)}. We briefly summarize three of such stochastic FL frameworks by pointing to the corresponding pre-data pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} and post-data qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}} distributions in Section 1.1 as examples of three different setups: (i) learning probability distributions over subnetworks (or masks), (ii) learning deterministic model parameters using stochastic compressors, and (iii) learning probability distributions over model parameters; and provide a more exhaustive summary in Section 2 and Appendix A. However, before that, we first give a rough outline of how 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} actually works.

Before describing the details of our proposal in Section 3, we now briefly provide the key idea 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} relies on: Instead of communicating the deterministic value of a sample 𝐱(t,n)∼qϕ(t,n)similar-tosuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑛subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)}\sim q_{\phi^{(t,n)}}, client n𝑛n can communicate a sample 𝐲(t,n)superscript𝐲𝑡𝑛\mathbf{y}^{(t,n)} from another distribution 𝐲(t,n)∼q~π(t,n)similar-tosuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑛subscript~𝑞superscript𝜋𝑡𝑛\mathbf{y}^{(t,n)}\sim\tilde{q}_{\pi^{(t,n)}}, which is less costly to communicate compared to 𝐱(t,n)superscript𝐱𝑡𝑛\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)}, and the discrepancy due to sampling from this distribution is not significant. As shown in Algorithm 1, to construct q~πsubscript~𝑞𝜋\tilde{q}_{\pi}, we use the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} (which is known by the server and the clients) and the importance sampling algorithm in [6].

We show that this procedure yields an arbitrarily small discrepancy in the estimation when K≃exp⁡(DK​L​(qϕ(n)∥pθ))similar-to-or-equals𝐾subscript𝐷𝐾𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscript𝑝𝜃K\simeq\exp\left(D_{KL}(q_{\phi^{(n)}}\|p_{\theta})\right) with theoretical and algorithmic improvements (specific to the FL setting) over prior work [16, 36]. Clearly, to get the most communication gain out of 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS}, we need pre-data pθsubscript𝑝𝜃p_{\theta} and post-data qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}} distributions that are close in KL divergence. We show the existence of such distributions in many stochastic FL frameworks by providing concrete examples in the next section.

1.1 Setups

We now briefly summarize three examples of stochastic FL frameworks that 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} can be integrated into by highlighting the natural choices for pre-data pθsubscript𝑝𝜃p_{\theta} and post-data qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}} distributions.

FedPM [19] freezes the parameters of a randomly initialized network and finds a subnetwork inside it that performs well with the initial random parameters. To find the subnetwork, the clients receive a global probability mask θ(t)∈[0,1]dsuperscript𝜃𝑡superscript01𝑑\theta^{(t)}\in[0,1]^{d} from the server that determines, for each parameter, the probability of retaining it in the subnetwork; set this as their local probability mask ϕ(t,n)←θ(t)←superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛superscript𝜃𝑡\phi^{(t,n)}\leftarrow\theta^{(t)}; and train only this mask (not the frozen random parameters) during local training. At inference, a sample x(t,n)∈{0,1}dsuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑛superscript01𝑑x^{(t,n)}\in\{0,1\}^{d} from the Bernoulli distribution Bern​(⋅;ϕ(t,n))Bern⋅superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\text{Bern}(\cdot;\phi^{(t,n)}) is taken, and multiplied element-wise with the frozen parameters of the network, obtaining a pruned random subnetwork, which is then used to compute the model outputs. Communication consists of three stages: (i) clients update their local probability masks ϕ(t,n)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\phi^{(t,n)} through local training; (ii) at the end of local training, they send a sample x(t,n)∼Bern​(⋅;ϕ(t,n))similar-tosuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑛Bern⋅superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛x^{(t,n)}\sim\text{Bern}(\cdot;\phi^{(t,n)}) to the server; (iii) the server aggregates the samples 1N​∑n=1Nx(t,n)1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝑥𝑡𝑛\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}x^{(t,n)}, updates the global probability mask θ(t+1)superscript𝜃𝑡1\theta^{(t+1)}, and broadcasts the new mask to the clients for the next round. FedPM achieves state-of-the-art results in accuracy-bitrate tradeoff with around 111 bit per parameter (bpp). (See Appendix A.1 for the full description.) As the model converges, the global probability mask θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} and clients’ local probability masks ϕ(t,n)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)} get closer to each other (see Figures 1 and 4 for the trend of DK​L(qϕ(t,n)||pθ(t)D_{KL}(q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}}||p_{\theta^{(t)}}) over time). However, no matter how close they are, FedPM employs approximately the same bitrate for communicating a sample from Bern​(⋅;ϕ(t,n))Bern⋅superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\text{Bern}(\cdot;\phi^{(t,n)}) to the server that knows pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}. We show that this strategy is suboptimal and applying 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} with the global probability distribution Bern​(⋅;θ(t))Bern⋅superscript𝜃𝑡\text{Bern}(\cdot;\theta^{(t)}) as the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}, and the local probability distribution Bern​(⋅;ϕ(t,n))Bern⋅superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\text{Bern}(\cdot;\phi^{(t,n)}) as the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}}, provides up to 505050 times gain in compression.

QSGD [2], different from the stochastic approach taken by FedPM to train a probabilistic mask, is proposed to train a deterministic set of parameters. However, QSGD is itself a stochastic quantization operation. More concretely, QSGD quantizes each coordinate 𝐯i(t,n)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i} using the following probability distribution (which we call the QSGD distribution pQSGD​(⋅)subscript𝑝QSGD⋅p_{\texttt{QSGD}}(\cdot)), where s𝑠s is the number of quantization levels (see Appendix A.2 for the full description):

pQSGD​(𝐯^i(t,n))={s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖−⌊s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖⌋if​𝐯^i(t,n)=‖𝐯(t,n)‖⋅sign​(𝐯i(t,n))s​(⌊s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖⌋+1) 1−s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖+⌊s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖⌋if​𝐯^i(t,n)=‖𝐯(t,n)‖⋅sign​(𝐯i(t,n))s​⌊s​|𝐯i(t,n)|‖𝐯(t,n)‖⌋.subscript𝑝QSGDsubscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖cases𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛ifsubscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖⋅normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛signsubscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖𝑠𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛11𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛ifsubscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖⋅normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛signsubscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖𝑠𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛\displaystyle p_{\texttt{QSGD}}\left(\mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i}\right)=\begin{cases}\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}-\left\lfloor\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}\right\rfloor\ &\text{if}\ \mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i}=\frac{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|\cdot\text{sign}(\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i})}{s}\left(\left\lfloor\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}\right\rfloor+1\right)\\ \ 1-\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}+\left\lfloor\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}\right\rfloor&\text{if}\ \mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i}=\frac{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|\cdot\text{sign}(\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i})}{s}\left\lfloor\frac{s|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}|}{\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|}\right\rfloor\end{cases}. (1)

QSGD takes advantage of the empirical distribution of the quantized values (large quantized values are less frequent) by using Elias coding to encode them – which is the preferred code when the small values to encode are much more frequent than the larger values [12]. However, QSGD still does not fully capture the distribution of the quantized values since Elias coding is not adaptive to the data. We fix this mismatch by applying 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} with the QSGD distribution pQSGD​(⋅)subscript𝑝QSGD⋅p_{\texttt{QSGD}}(\cdot) as the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}}, and the empirical distribution induced by the historical updates at the server from the previous round as the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}. These two distributions are expected to be close to each other due to the temporal correlation across rounds, as previously reported by [20, 31]. We demonstrate that 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} exploits this closeness and outperforms vanilla QSGD with a 121212 times improvement in bitrate.

Federated SGLD [11] targets a Bayesian FL setup, where the goal is to learn a global posterior distribution pθsubscript𝑝𝜃p_{\mathbf{\theta}} over the model parameters from clients’ local posteriors qϕ(n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛q_{\phi^{(n)}}. A state-of-the-art method proposed in [41] is the federated counterpart of the Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD) [43], which uses a novel Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm. In this setting, the global posterior distribution is assumed to be proportional to the product pθ(t)∼∏n=1Ne−U​(ϕ(t,n))similar-tosubscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁superscript𝑒𝑈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛p_{\theta^{(t)}}\sim\prod_{n=1}^{N}e^{-U(\phi^{(t,n)})} of N𝑁N local unnormalized posteriors associated with each client, expressed as potential functions {U​(ϕ(t,n))}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝑈superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{U(\phi^{(t,n)})\}_{n=1}^{N}. At the beginning of each local training round, the local clients’ posteriors are initialized with the global posterior ϕ(n,t)←θ(t),∀n∈[N]formulae-sequence←superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\phi^{(n,t)}\leftarrow\theta^{(t)},\;\forall n\in[N]. Then the clients compute an unbiased estimate of their gradients H​(ϕ(t,n))=|D(n)||𝒮(t,n)|​∑j∈𝒮(t,n)∇Uj​(ϕ(t,n))𝐻superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛superscript𝐷𝑛superscript𝒮𝑡𝑛subscript𝑗superscript𝒮𝑡𝑛∇subscript𝑈𝑗superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛H(\phi^{(t,n)})=\frac{|D^{(n)}|}{|\mathcal{S}^{(t,n)}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}^{(t,n)}}\nabla U_{j}(\phi^{(t,n)}), where |D(n)|superscript𝐷𝑛|D^{(n)}| is the size of the local dataset of client n𝑛n, and 𝒮(t,n)superscript𝒮𝑡𝑛\mathcal{S}^{(t,n)} is the batch of data used to estimate the gradient. They then communicate these estimates to the server, which aggregates them by computing

θ(t+1)=θ(t)−γ​∑n=1NH​(ϕ(t,n))+2​γ​ξ(t),superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁𝐻superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛2𝛾superscript𝜉𝑡\displaystyle\theta^{(t+1)}=\theta^{(t)}-\gamma\sum_{n=1}^{N}H(\phi^{(t,n)})+\sqrt{2\gamma}\xi^{(t)}, (2)

where ξ(t)superscript𝜉𝑡\xi^{(t)} is a sequence of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables. (See Appendix A.3 for the details.) As reported in [11, 41], the sequence of global updates θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} converges to the posterior sampling. Notice that the clients communicate their gradient vectors H​(ϕ(t,n))𝐻superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛H(\phi^{(t,n)}) to the server at every round, which is as large as the model itself. To reduce this communication cost, in [41], the authors propose a compression algorithm called QLSD that stochastically quantizes the updates with essentially the Bayesian counterpart of QSGD [2]. However, neither QLSD nor the other compression baselines in the Bayesian FL literature [7, 10, 32] take full advantage of the stochastic formulation of the Bayesian framework, where the server and the clients share side information (the global posterior pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}) that could be used to improve the compression gains. Instead, they quantize the updates ignoring this side information. This approach is suboptimal since (i) the precision is already degraded in the quantization step, and (ii) the compression step does not account for the side information pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}. We show that we can exploit this inherent stochastic formulation of Bayesian FL by applying 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} with the global posterior distribution as the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\mathbf{\theta}^{(t)}}, and the local posterior distribution as the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}}. In addition to benefiting from the side information, 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} does not restrict the message domain to be discrete (as opposed to the baselines) and can reduce the communication cost by 444 times, while also achieving higher accuracy than the baselines.

1.2 Contributions

We have listed three examples of stochastic communication-efficient FL frameworks, each of which induces a post-data distribution qθ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscript𝜃𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\theta}^{(t,n)}} that clients want to send a sample from, and a pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} that is available to both the clients and the server – playing the role of side information. In each case, these distributions are expected to become closer in KL divergence as training progresses due to the convergence of the model parameters (FedPM or other probabilistic mask learning methods), temporal correlation across rounds (QSGD or other deterministic model training methods), or the stochastic formulation of the framework itself (Federated SGLD or other Bayesian FL methods). We show that 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} reduces the communication cost down to this fundamental quantity (KL divergence) in each scenario, resulting in up to 505050 times improvement in communication efficiency (sometimes with higher accuracies) over FedPM, QLSD, and QSGD among other non-stochastic competitive baselines such as SignSGD [5], TernGrad [44], DRIVE [38], EDEN [39], and FedMask [25]. To achieve this efficiency, we use an importance sampling algorithm [6, 15] by improving and extending the previous theoretical guarantees to the distributed setting. Different from prior work that used importance sampling in the centralized setting to compress model parameters [16] or focused on differential privacy implications [33, 36], 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} selects more natural pre-data pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\mathbf{\theta}^{(t)}} and post-data qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}} distributions that are intrinsic to the FL setting, and optimizes the bit allocation across both the training rounds and the model coordinates in an adaptive way to achieve the optimal bitrate, while also eliminating a hyperparameter required by prior work [16, 36]. Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

(1) We propose a road map to utilize various forms of side information available to both the server and the clients to reduce the communication cost in FL. We give concrete examples of how to code model updates under different setups, including probabilistic mask training (e.g., FedPM), deterministic model training with stochastic compressors (e.g., QSGD), and Bayesian FL (e.g., Federated SGLD).

(2) We extend the importance sampling results to the distributed setting with theoretical improvements.

(3) We propose an adaptive bit allocation strategy that eliminates a hyperparameter required by prior work, and allows a better use of the communication budget across the model coordinates and rounds.

(4) We demonstrate the efficacy of our strategy on MNIST, EMNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets, and show improvements in accuracy with up to 505050 times gains in bitrate (with sometimes higher accuracies) over relevant baselines such as FedPM [19], QLSD [41], QSGD [2], SignSGD [5], TernGrad [44], DRIVE [38], EDEN [39], FedMask [25], and DP-REC [36].

2 Related Work

Communication-Efficient FL: There has been extensive research in reducing the communication cost of FL (i) by compressing the model updates through sparsification [1, 3, 26, 31, 42], quantization [28, 34, 41, 44], and low-rank factorization [4, 29, 40, 42]; or (ii) by training sparse subnetworks instead of the full model [19, 24, 25, 27, 30, 37]. Among these approaches, those based on stochastic updates have shown success over the deterministic ones in similar settings. For instance, for finding sparse subnetworks within a large random model, FedPM [19] takes a stochastic approach by training a probability mask, indicating the probability for each random model parameter to be part of the subnetwork, and extracting those subnetworks by taking samples from the distribution parameterized by the trained probability mask. With this approach, FedPM outperforms other methods that find sparse subnetworks [25, 30, 37] with significant accuracy and bitrate gains. Similarly, for the standard FL setting (training model parameters), QSGD [2] is an effective stochastic quantization method – outperforming most other quantization schemes such as SignSGD [5] and TernGrad [44] by large margins. Lastly, in the Bayesian FL setting, QLSD [41] proposes a Bayesian counterpart of QSGD, and performs better than other baselines [7, 10, 32]. While all these stochastic approaches already perform better than the relevant baselines, in this work, we show that they do not take full advantage of the side information available to the server. We provide a guideline on how to find useful side information under each setting and introduce 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} that reduces the communication cost to the fundamental distance between the client’s distribution that they want to communicate samples from and the side information at the server (with 505050 times reduced communication cost compared to the baselines).

Importance Sampling: Our strategy is inspired by the importance sampling algorithm studied in [6, 15, 35], and later applied for model compression [16], learned image compression [13, 14], and compressing differentially private mechanisms [33, 36]. One relevant work to ours is [16], which applies the importance sampling strategy in [6] to compress Bayesian neural networks. Since the model size is too large to be compressed at once, they compress fixed-size blocks of the model parameters separately and independently. As we elaborate in Section 3, this can be done much more efficiently by choosing the block size adaptively based on the information content of each parameter. While this adaptive strategy could bring some extra communication overhead when applied for model compression (to locate the adaptive-size blocks), we explain how to avoid this overhead in the FL setting by exploiting temporal correlations. Another relevant work is DP-REC [36], which again applies the importance sampling technique in [6] to compress the model updates in FL, while also showing differential privacy implications. However, since their training strategy is fully deterministic (no probabilistic learning or stochastic compression), the choice of pre-data and post-data distributions is somewhat arbitrary. Instead, in our work, the goal is to exploit the available side information to the full extent by choosing natural pre-data and post-data distributions – which improves the communication efficiency over DP-REC significantly. Another factor in this improvement is the adaptive bit allocation strategy mentioned above – which could actually be integrated into DP-REC as well by avoiding the extra communication overhead as we do in our work (since DP-REC works in an FL setting too). Our experimental results demonstrate that these two improvements are indeed critical for boosting the accuracy-bitrate tradeoff. Finally, we extend the theoretical guarantees of importance sampling, which quantifies the required bitrate for a target discrepancy (due to compression), to the distributed setting, where we can recover the existing results in [6] as a special case by setting N=1𝑁1N=1.

3 KL Divergence Minimization with Side Information (KLMS)

We first describe our approach, 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS}, in Section 3.1 together with theoretical guarantees; then, in Section 3.2, we introduce our adaptive bit allocation strategy to optimize the bitrate across training rounds and model coordinates to reduce the compression rate; finally, in Section 3.3, we give four concrete examples where 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} improves the accuracy-bitrate tradeoff.

3.1 KLMS for Stochastic FL Frameworks

We first point out that our proposal is not a stand-alone FL framework to replace existing alternatives, rather, it represents a general recipe that can be integrated into many existing (stochastic) frameworks to improve their accuracy-bitrate performance significantly. The main idea behind 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} is grounded in three important observations:

(1) In many existing FL frameworks, the updates communicated from the clients to the server are samples drawn from some optimized post-data distributions, e.g., QSGD [2] and FedPM [19].

(2) Sending a random sample from a distribution can be done much more efficiently than first taking a sample from the same distribution, and then sending its deterministic value [35].

(3) The knowledge acquired from the historical updates, available both at the server and the clients, can help reduce the communication cost drastically by playing the role of side information.

𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} is designed to reduce the communication cost in FL by taking advantage of the above observations. It relies on common randomness between the clients and the server in the form of a random SEED (i.e., they can generate the same random samples from the same distribution) and also on the side information available to the server and the clients. Without restricting ourselves to any specific FL framework (we will do this in Section 3.3), suppose the server and the clients share a pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}, and each client has a post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}} after the local training steps. As stated in Section 1, the goal of the server is to compute 𝔼X(t,n)∼qϕ(t,n),∀n∈[N]​[1N​∑n=1NX(t,n)]subscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscript𝑋𝑡𝑛subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝑋𝑡𝑛\mathbb{E}_{X^{(t,n)}\sim q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}},\forall n\in[N]}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}X^{(t,n)}\right] after each round. While this can be done by simply communicating samples 𝐱(t,n)∼qϕ(t,n)similar-tosuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑛subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\mathbf{x}^{(t,n)}\sim q_{\mathbf{\phi}^{(t,n)}}, we note that the communicated samples do not need to be the exact same samples that are generated at the client’s side. 3.2 Adaptive Block Selection for Optimal Bit Allocation

Prior works that have applied importance sampling for Bayesian neural network compression [16], or for differentially private communication in FL [36] split the model into several fixed-size blocks of parameters, and compress each block separately and independently to avoid the high computational cost – which exponentially increases with the number of parameters d𝑑d. After splitting the model into fixed-size blocks with S𝑆S parameters each, [16, 36] choose a single fixed K𝐾K (number of samples generated from pθ(t)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝜃𝑡p_{\theta}^{(t)}) for each block no matter what the KL divergence is for different blocks. This yields the same bitrate log⁡KS𝐾𝑆\frac{\log K}{S} for every model parameter. Furthermore, [36] uses the same K𝐾K throughout training without considering the variation in KL divergence over rounds. However, as illustrated in Figure 1, KL divergence changes significantly across different layers of the model and across rounds. Hence, spending the same bitrate log⁡KS𝐾𝑆\frac{\log K}{S} for every parameter at every round is highly suboptimal since it breaks the condition in Theorem 3.1.

To fix this, we propose an adaptive block selection mechanism, where the block size is adjusted such that the KL divergence for each block is the same and equal to a target value, DK​Ltargetsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿targetD_{KL}^{\text{target}}. This way, the optimal K𝐾K for each block is the same and approximately equal to DK​Ltargetsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿targetD_{KL}^{\text{target}}, and we do not need to set the block size S𝑆S ourselves, which was a hyperparameter to tune in [16, 36]. Different from the fixed-size block selection approach in [16, 36], the adaptive approach requires describing the locations of the adaptive-size blocks, which adds overhead to the communication cost. However, exploiting the temporal correlation across rounds can make this overhead negligible. More specifically, we first let each client find their adaptive-size blocks, each having KL divergence equal to DK​Ltargetsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿targetD_{KL}^{\text{target}}, in the first round. Then the clients communicate the locations of these blocks to the server, which are then aggregated by the server to find the new global indices to be broadcast to the clients, i.e., federated aggregation of block locations. At later rounds, the server checks if, on average, the new KL divergence of the previous blocks is still sufficiently close to the target value DK​Ltargetsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿targetD_{KL}^{\text{target}}. If so, the same adaptive-size blocks are used in that round. Otherwise, the client constructs new blocks, each having KL divergence equal to DK​Ltargetsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿targetD_{KL}^{\text{target}}, and updates the server about the new locations. Our experiments indicate that this update occurs only a few times during the whole training. Therefore, it adds only a negligible overhead on the average communication cost across rounds. We provide the pseudocodes for 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} with both fixed- and adaptive-size blocks in Appendix B.

3.3 Examples of 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} Adaptated to Well-Known Stochastic FL Frameworks

In this section, we provide four concrete examples illustrating how 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} can be naturally integrated into different FL frameworks with natural choices of pre-data and post-data distributions. Later, in Section 4, we present experimental results showing the empirical improvements 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} brings in all these cases. The corresponding pseudocodes are given in Appendix D.

FedPM-KLMS: As described in Section 1.1, in FedPM [19], the server holds a global probability mask, which parameterizes a probability distribution over the mask parameters – indicating for each model parameter, with what probability it should remain in the subnetwork. Similarly, each client obtains a local probability mask after local training – parameterizing their locally updated probability assignment for each model parameter to remain in the subnetwork. Choosing the global probability mask θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} as the parameters of the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} and the local probability mask ϕ(t,n)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\phi^{(t,n)} as the parameters of the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}} is only natural since the goal in [19] is to send a sample from the local probability distribution Bern​(⋅;ϕ(t,n))Bern⋅superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛\text{Bern}(\cdot;\phi^{(t,n)}) with as few bits as possible. This new framework, FedPM-KLMS, provides 505050 times reduction in bitrate over vanilla FedPM.

QSGD-KLMS: As explained in detail in Section 1.1, QSGD [2] is a stochastic quantization method for FL frameworks that train deterministic model parameters, which outperforms many other baselines in the same setting. Focusing on the most extreme case when the number of quantization levels is s=1𝑠1s=1, we can express the QSGD distribution in (1) as follows:

which is again a very natural choice of post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}} since vanilla QSGD requires the clients to take a sample from pQSGD​(⋅)subscript𝑝QSGD⋅p_{\texttt{QSGD}}(\cdot) in (6) and communicate the deterministic value of that sample to the server. As for the pre-data distribution, exploiting the temporal correlation in FL, we use the empirical frequencies of the historical updates the server received in the previous round. In other words, in every round t𝑡t, the server records how many clients communicated a negative value (corresponding to −‖𝐯(t,n)‖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛-\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|), a positive value (corresponding to ‖𝐯(t,n)‖normsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛\|\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}\|), or 00 per coordinate, and constructs the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}} from these empirical frequencies for the next rounds. This new framework, QSGD-KLMS, yields 121212 times reduction in bitrate over vanilla QSGD.

SignSGD-KLMS: Since SignSGD [5] is not a stochastic quantizer, we first introduce some stochasticity to the vanilla SignSGD algorithm and then integrate 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} into it. Instead of mapping the updates to their signs ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 deterministically as in vanilla SignSGD, the stochastic version we propose does this mapping by taking a sample from the following SignSGD distribution

pSignSGD​(𝐯^i(t,n))={Sigmoid​(𝐯i(t,n)M)if ​𝐯^i(t,n)=11−Sigmoid​(𝐯i(t,n)M)if ​𝐯^i(t,n)=−1,subscript𝑝SignSGDsubscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖casesSigmoidsubscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖𝑀if subscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖11Sigmoidsubscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖𝑀if subscriptsuperscript^𝐯𝑡𝑛𝑖1\displaystyle p_{\texttt{SignSGD}}(\mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i})=\begin{cases}\text{Sigmoid}(\frac{\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}}{M})\ &\text{if }\ \mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i}=1\\ 1-\text{Sigmoid}(\frac{\mathbf{v}^{(t,n)}_{i}}{M})\ &\text{if }\ \mathbf{\hat{v}}^{(t,n)}_{i}=-1\end{cases}, (7)

for some M>0𝑀0M>0. Instead of taking a sample from pSignSGD​(⋅)subscript𝑝SignSGD⋅p_{\texttt{SignSGD}}(\cdot) and sending the deterministic value of the sample by spending 111 bpp, we can take advantage of the sign symmetry in the model update (about half of the coordinates have positive/negative signs in the update) and reduce the communication cost. For this, we choose pSignSGD​(⋅)subscript𝑝SignSGD⋅p_{\texttt{SignSGD}}(\cdot) in (7) as the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}}, and the uniform distribution U​(0.5)𝑈0.5U(0.5) from the support {−1,1}11\{-1,1\} as the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}. This new method, SignSGD-KLMS, achieves higher accuracy than vanilla SignSGD with 606060 times smaller bitrate.

SGLD-KLMS: From the Bayesian FL family, we focus on the recent SGLD framework [41] as an example since it provides state-of-the-art results. As explained in detail in Section 1.1, due to the stochastic formulation of the Bayesian framework, it is natural to choose the local posterior distributions as the post-data distribution qϕ(t,n)subscript𝑞superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑛q_{\phi^{(t,n)}}, and the global posterior distribution at the server as the pre-data distribution pθ(t)subscript𝑝superscript𝜃𝑡p_{\theta^{(t)}}. While extending the existing SGLD algorithm (see Section 1.1) with KLMS, we inject Gaussian noise locally at each client and scale it such that when all the samples are averaged at the server, the aggregate noise sample ξ(t)superscript𝜉𝑡\xi^{(t)} (see Eq. (2)) is distributed according to 𝒩​(0,𝑰d)𝒩0subscript𝑰𝑑\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I}_{d}) (more details in Appendix D). This new framework, SGLD-KLMS, provides both accuracy and bitrate gains over QLSD [41] – the state-of-the-art compression method for Federated SGLD.

4 Experiments

We empirically demonstrate the accuracy and bitrate improvements obtained with 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} by focusing on four 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} adaptations we covered in Section 3.3. We consider four datasets: CIFAR-10 [23], CIFAR-100 [23], MNIST [9], and EMNIST [8] (with 47 classes). For CIFAR-100, we use ResNet-18 [17]; for CIFAR-10, a 6-layer CNN CONV6; for MNIST a 4-layer CNN CONV4 and LeNet; and for EMNIST, again CONV4. Additional details on the experimental setup and more detailed results with confidence intervals can be found in Appendices E and F. We first compare FedPM-KLMS, QSGD-KLMS, and SignSGD-KLMS with FedPM [19], QSGD [2], SignSGD [5], TernGrad [44], DRIVE [38], EDEN [39], FedMask [25], and DP-REC [36] on non-Bayesian FL setting in Section 4.1. We then provide a comparison of SGLD-KLMS with QLSD [41] on the Bayesian FL setting in Section 4.2. Finally, in Section 4.3, we present a key ablation study to show how the adaptive block selection strategy in Section 3.2 optimizes the bit allocation and helps achieve a smaller bitrate. Clients perform 333 and 111 local epochs in the non-Bayesian and Bayesian settings, respectively. (Results averaged over 333 runs.)

4.1 Non-Bayesian Federated Learning

i.i.d. Data Split: For the i.i.d. dataset experiments in Figure 2, we set the number of clients to N=10𝑁10N=10 and consider full client participation. As can be seen from Figure 2, FedPM-KLMS and SignSGD-KLMS provide 505050 times reduction in communication cost compared to FedPM and SignSGD, respectively (together with the accuracy boost over vanilla SignSGD). QSGD-KLMS, on the other hand, reduces the communication cost by 121212 times over vanilla QSGD. Overall, among our baselines, QSGD requires the smallest bitrate, and FedPM achieves the highest accuracy. Surprisingly, FedPM-KLMS requires 101010 times smaller bitrate than QSGD while achieving the same accuracy as FedPM at the same time – consistently in all the experiments. The consistent and significant improvements over DP-REC (in both bitrate and accuracy) justify the importance of (i) carefully choosing the pre-data and post-data distributions, and (ii) the adaptive block selection that optimizes the bit allocation.

Non-i.i.d. Data Split: For the non-i.i.d. experiments in Figure 3, we only compare against the best of our baselines from the i.i.d. results – namely FedPM, QSGD, DRIVE, EDEN, and DP-REC. We set the number of clients to N=100𝑁100N=100 and let randomly sampled 202020 of them participate in each round. We explain the non-i.i.d. split strategy in Appendix E. Let cmaxsubscript𝑐maxc_{\text{max}} be the maximum number of classes each client can see due to the non-i.i.d. split data. In the experiments in Figure 3, we set cmax=20subscript𝑐max20c_{\text{max}}=20 for CIFAR-100 and cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4 for CIFAR-10. (See Appendix F for cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2 results.) Figure 3 shows similar gains over the baselines as the i.i.d. experiments in Figure 2; in that, KLMS adaptations provide up to 505050 times reduction in the communication cost compared to the baselines with final accuracy as high as the best baseline. This indicates that the statistical heterogeneity level in the data split, while reducing the performance of the underlying training schemes, does not affect the improvement brought by KLMS. We further corroborate this observation with additional experiments in Appendix F.1.2.

4.2 Bayesian Federated Learning

We present the comparison of SGLD-KLMS with QLSD [41] in Figure 4-(left). We consider i.i.d. data split and full client participation with the number of clients N=10𝑁10N=10. It is seen that SGLD-KLMS can reduce the communication cost by 555 times more than QLSD with higher accuracy on MNIST, where in this case the accuracy is a Monte Carlo average obtained by posterior sampling after convergence.

4.3 Ablation Study: The Effect of the Adaptive Bit Allocation Strategy

We conduct an ablation study to answer the following question: Does adaptive bit allocation strategy really help optimize the bit allocation and reduce ##\# bits down to KL divergence? To answer this question, in Figure 4-(right), we show how the average per-parameter KL divergence and ##\# bits spent per parameter change over the rounds for FedPM-KLMS with fixed- and adaptive-size blocks. We adjust the hyperparameters such that the final accuracies differ by only 0.01%percent0.010.01\% on CIFAR-10. For the fixed-size experiments, since we fix K𝐾K (number of samples per block) and the block size for the whole model and across rounds, ##\# bits per parameter stays the same while the KL divergence shows a decreasing trend. On the other hand, in the adaptive-size experiments, the block size changes across the model parameters and the rounds to guarantee that each block has the same KL divergence. Since all blocks have the same KL divergence, we spend the same ##\# bits for each block as suggested by Theorem 3.1, which adaptively optimizes the bitrate towards the KL divergence. This is indeed justified in Figure 4-(right) since the ##\# bits curve quickly approaches the KL divergence curve.

5 Discussion & Conclusion

We introduced KL Divergence Minimization with Side Information (KLMS) – a recipe for reducing the communication cost in stochastic FL frameworks by exploiting the side information available to the server and correlated with the local model updates. We highlighted the existence of highly natural choices of pre-data distribution (side information at the server) and post-data distribution (at the clients) in FL that we can take advantage of to reduce the communication cost significantly. Moreover, we showed how to adaptively adjust the bitrate across the model parameters and training rounds to achieve the fundamental communication cost – the KL divergence between the pre-data and post-data distributions. While we showed four KLMS adaptations that reduce the communication cost 505050 times more than our baselines and still preserve (sometimes improve) the accuracy, it can be adapted to many other stochastic FL frameworks and can provide similar communication gains.

Limitations and Broader Impact: In our empirical evaluations, we tested our framework 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} by comparing the accuracy and bitrate tradeoffs. However, we acknowledge that compressing model updates via either our baselines or 𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂𝙺𝙻𝙼𝚂\mathtt{KLMS} may also degrade other properties of the trained model, such as fairness, robustness, and data leakage. We agree that these considerations deserve more attention from the communication-efficient FL community for more rigorous evaluations.

Proof.

Let L(n)=DK​L(qϕ(n)||pθ),∀n∈[N]L^{(n)}=D_{KL}(q_{\phi^{(n)}}||p_{\theta}),\forall n\in[N]. Suppose that K(n)=eL(n)+rsuperscript𝐾𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟K^{(n)}=e^{L^{(n)}+r} and a(n)=eL(n)+r/2superscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟2a^{(n)}=e^{L^{(n)}+r/2}. Let h​(z)=f​(z)ℎ𝑧𝑓𝑧h(z)=f(z) if ρn​(z)≤a(n)subscript𝜌𝑛𝑧superscript𝑎𝑛\rho_{n}(z)\leq a^{(n)} and 00 otherwise ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. We first make the following assumption:

𝔼[|1N∑n∈Q⊆[N]f(X(n))|;∀n∈Q⊆[N],ρn(X(n))>a(n)]≤𝔼[|1N∑n∈[N]f(X(n)|;∀n∈[N],ρn(X(n))>a(n)].\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in Q\subseteq[N]}f(X^{(n)})|;\forall n\in Q\subseteq[N],\rho_{n}(X^{(n)})>a^{(n)}]\leq\\ \mathbb{E}[|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in[N]}f(X^{(n})|;\forall n\in[N],\rho_{n}(X^{(n)})>a^{(n)}].\end{aligned} (16)

This is indeed a reasonable assumption. To see this, following [6], we note that log⁡ρn​(Z)subscript𝜌𝑛𝑍\log\rho_{n}(Z) is concentrated around its expected value, which is L(n)=DK​L(qϕ(n)||pθ)L^{(n)}=D_{KL}(q_{\phi^{(n)}}||p_{\theta}), in many scenarios. Therefore, for small t𝑡t (and t𝑡t is indeed negligibly small in our experiments), the events 𝟏{∀n∈Q⊆[N],ρn(X(n))>a(n)}\mathbf{1}\{\forall n\in Q\subseteq[N],\rho_{n}(X^{(n)})>a^{(n)}\} occur with the approximately same frequency for each set Q⊆[N]𝑄delimited-[]𝑁Q\subseteq[N] since the likelihood of event 𝟏​{ρn​(X(n))>a(n)}1subscript𝜌𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑎𝑛\mathbf{1}\{\rho_{n}(X^{(n)})>a^{(n)}\} is close to being uniform. Consider also that |1N​∑n∈Q⊆[N]f​(X(n))|≤|1N​∑n∈[N]f​(X(n))|1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑄delimited-[]𝑁𝑓superscript𝑋𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑛delimited-[]𝑁𝑓superscript𝑋𝑛|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in Q\subseteq[N]}f(X^{(n)})|\leq|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n\in[N]}f(X^{(n)})| holds when f​(Xn)𝑓superscript𝑋𝑛f(X^{n})’s have the same signs per coordinate for each n=1,…,N𝑛1…𝑁n=1,\dots,N, which is a realistic assumption given that the clients are assumed to be able to train a joint model and hence should not have opposite signs in the updates very often. With these two observations, we argue that the assumption in (16) is indeed reasonable for many scenarios, including FL.

Now, we restate Theorem 3.1 below and provide the proof afterward.

Theorem C.2 (Theorem 3.1).

Let all notations be as in Theorem C.1 and let JK​(f)subscript𝐽𝐾𝑓J_{K}(f) be the estimate defined in (13). Suppose that K(n)=exp⁡(L(n)+r)superscript𝐾𝑛superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟K^{(n)}=\exp{\left(L^{(n)}+r\right)} for some r≥0𝑟0r\geq 0. Let

ϵ=(e−N​r/4+2​∏n=1Nℙ​(log⁡ρn​(X(n))>L(n)+r/2))1/2.italic-ϵsuperscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑁𝑟42superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1𝑁ℙsubscript𝜌𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟212\displaystyle\epsilon=\left(e^{-Nr/4}+2\sqrt{\prod_{n=1}^{N}\mathbb{P}(\log\rho_{n}(X^{(n)})>L^{(n)}+r/2)}\right)^{1/2}. (43)

Then

Proof.

Suppose that K(n)=eL(n)+rsuperscript𝐾𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟K^{(n)}=e^{L^{(n)}+r} and a(n)=eL(n)+r/2superscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝐿𝑛𝑟2a^{(n)}=e^{L^{(n)}+r/2} ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. Let

(45)

Then, by Theorem C.1, for any ϵ,δ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ𝛿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1),

and

Appendix E Additional Experimental Details

In Tables 1,  2, and 3, we provide the architectures for all the models used in our experiments, namely CONV4, CONV6, ResNet-18, and LeNet. In the non-Bayesian experiments, clients performed three local epochs with a batch size of 128 and a local learning rate of 0.1; while in the Bayesian experiments, they performed one local epoch. We conducted our experiments on NVIDIA Titan X GPUs on an internal cluster server, using 1 GPU per one run.

During non-i.i.d. data split, we choose the size of each client’s dataset |𝒟(n)|=Dnsuperscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛|\mathcal{D}^{(n)}|=D_{n} by first uniformly sampling an integer jnsubscript𝑗𝑛j_{n} from {10,11,…,100}1011…100\{10,11,\dots,100\}. Then, a coefficient jn∑njjsubscript𝑗𝑛subscript𝑛subscript𝑗𝑗\frac{j_{n}}{\sum_{n}j_{j}} is computed, representing the size of the local dataset Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} as a fraction of the full training dataset size. Moreover, we impose a maximum number of different labels, or classes, cmaxsubscript𝑐maxc_{\text{max}}, that each client can see. This way, highly unbalanced local datasets are generated.

Appendix F Additional Experimental Results

F.1 KLMS on a Toy Model

We provide additional insights on KLMS employed in a distributed setup similar to that of FL. Specifically, we design a set of experiments in which the server keeps a pre-data distribution p=𝒩​(0,1)𝑝𝒩01p=\mathcal{N}(0,1), and N𝑁N clients need to communicate samples according to their local post-data distributions {q(n)}n=1N={𝒩​(μ(n),1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑛𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒩superscript𝜇𝑛1𝑛1𝑁\{q^{(n)}\}_{n=1}^{N}=\{\mathcal{N}\left(\mu^{(n)},1\right)\}_{n=1}^{N}, which are induced by a global and unknown distribution q=𝒩​(μ,1)𝑞𝒩𝜇1q=\mathcal{N}\left(\mu,1\right). Each client n𝑛n applies KLMS (see Algorithm 1) to communicate a sample x(n)superscript𝑥𝑛x^{(n)} from q(n)superscript𝑞𝑛q^{(n)} using as coding distribution the pre-data distribution p𝑝p. The server then computes μ^=1N​∑n=1Nx(n)^𝜇1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝑥𝑛\hat{\mu}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}x^{(n)} to estimate μ𝜇\mu. We study the effect of N𝑁N, i.e., the number of clients communicating their samples, on the estimation of μ𝜇\mu in different scenarios by varying the rate adopted by the clients (Appenix F.1.1), and the complexity of the problem (Appendix F.1.2).

F.1.1 The effect of the overhead r𝑟r

In this example, we simulate an i.i.d. data split by providing all the clients with the same local post-data distribution q(n)=𝒩​(0.8,1)superscript𝑞𝑛𝒩0.81q^{(n)}=\mathcal{N}\left(0.8,1\right) ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. We analyze the bias in the estimation of μ𝜇\mu by computing a Monte Carlo average of the discrepancy in (3) (see Figure 5-(right)), together with its empirical standard deviation (see Figure 5-(left)). From Figure 5, we can observe that, as conjectured, the standard deviation of the gap decreases when N𝑁N increases, meaning that the estimation is more accurate around its mean value, which is also better for larger values of N𝑁N. Also, as expected, a larger value of the overhead r𝑟r induces better accuracy.

F.1.2 The effect of non-i.i.d. data split

In this other set of experiments we simulate a non-i.i.d. data split by inducing, starting from the same pre-data distribution p𝑝p, different local post-data distributions, simulating drifts in updates statistics due to data heterogeneity. Specifically, we set again μ=0.8𝜇0.8\mu=0.8, and then, ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N], μ(n)=0.8+u(n)superscript𝜇𝑛0.8superscript𝑢𝑛\mu^{(n)}=0.8+u^{(n)}, where u(n)∼Unif​([−η,η])similar-tosuperscript𝑢𝑛Unif𝜂𝜂u^{(n)}\sim\text{Unif}([-\eta,\eta]), for η∈{0.05,0.1,0.25,0.4}𝜂0.050.10.250.4\eta\in\{0.05,0.1,0.25,0.4\}. In all experiments, r=6𝑟6r=6. As we can see from Figure 6, when N𝑁N is very small (∼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1), then high level of heterogeneity in the update statistics can indeed lead to poor estimation accuracy. However, for reasonable values of N𝑁N, this effect is considerably mitigated, suggesting that for real-world applications of FL, where the number of devices participating to each round can be very large, KLMS can still improve state-of-the-art compression schemes by large margin, as reported in the results of Section 4.1 and Appendix F.2.

F.2 Additional Results

Now, we present additional experimental results that we skipped in the main body due to page limitation. First, in Figure 7, we give the results on CONV6 and ResNet-18 on non-i.i.d. CIFAR-10 with cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2 and CIFAR-100 with cmax=20subscript𝑐max20c_{\text{max}}=20, respectively. In both experiments, 101010 clients out of 100100100 clients participate in each round. It is seen that similar accuracy and bitrate improvements are observed to the non-i.i.d. results in Figure 3.

Finally, we report the confidence intervals for all the experimental results in the paper in Tables 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 11 corresponding to Figures 2, 3, and 7.
